rv: yeah, we should find a more up-to-date source than the LSI, but it will still need to be a source that supports the content we're adding (the two added sources did not support the text: one noted efforts to promote Bajjika in India, the other simply mentioned it as spoken in Nepal; neither indicated anything about classification or sociolinguistics)

rv c&p move

Linguistics don't change with time. Stop editing and putting wrong information to misguide people. Languages and dialects are defined by Linguists not by government. Politics and linguistics are two different things. There can be political classification of a language but linguistic classification don't change and it is only original classification.
/* Politeness */Tum is not used Bhojpuri, Tu is used
